awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Organizational Control and Worker Experience in Creative Industries
awd_abstract_narration:
Work in the 21st century is characterized both by insecure employment and increasing numbers of jobs in knowledge and creative industries that require creativity on the part of workers.  Many of the workers in these industries work as freelancers in geographically dispersed locations. These characteristics of work in the contemporary economy raise three questions that are the focus of this research: (1) how do workers come to find insecure, uncertain work situations desirable? (2) how do modern organizations control and structure the way people do their work in the absence of requiring workers to be in a single work place.  Given the importance of information and communication technologies in the workplace, this study also asks (3) how workplace technologies affect creative workers. To answer these questions, this project compares the working days of two very different types of workers- freelance work performed by YouTube content producers in digital media and audio engineers in popular music compared to data processors in digital media and recording studio office workers in popular music. The first group of workers do more creative work and the second group does more routine work though both work in creative industries. The researcher will conduct ethnographic observations of these workers' everyday experiences to develop a greater understanding of the experiences of workers in these economically important, creative industries. 

This project builds upon research within the sociologies of labor, organizations, technology, and art. Addressing the sociology of labor and work's perennial concern regarding organizational control, this research seeks to explain how post-bureaucratic and "virtual" organizations in these industries maintain control over work processes in the absence of clear hierarchies and geographically dispersed employees. Addressing recent developments in the sociology of the arts, this project focuses on the role of workers' aesthetic experience vis-à-vis organizational artifacts (e.g. technology and media) in explaining workers' consent to their conditions of employment. Last, this project addresses theoretical concerns related to materiality and technology inside organizations by examining the discursive and socio-material practices associated with "creativity" in these industries. Much research on work in creative industries uses only interview data and thus tends to exclude the concrete experiences and everyday meaning making of workers. Empirically, this project extends research on creative work by drawing on ethnographic data gathered through 24 months of participant observation, in-depth, interviews, and audio-visual data collection methods (i.e., audio recordings documenting the sounds of the working day and photographic documentation).

Overview and Research Questions

Michael L. Siciliano has completed research for his dissertation entitled Creative Control: Labor relations, Technology, and Aesthetics in the Culture Industry. During the funding period he spent time interviewing digital content producers in the Midwestern, Southwestern, and Western U.S. This research formed part of a research project that

 compared the work processes of creative and routine employees in two organizations within the information sector of the U.S. economy (a popular music production studio and a YouTube content production company). As a sociologist of labor and culture, Michael Siciliano was interested in answering three questions: (1) What skills and competencies are required of employees and does this vary between creative and routine employees in these industries? (2) How do organizations attempt to foster and control creativity at work and how, if at all, does this vary between routine and creative employees? And finally, (3) what effects do new forms of organizing work such as digital platforms (e.g., YouTube) have upon work processes in the information sector?

 

Primary Findings

In order to answer these questions, Michael L. Siciliano undertook 19 months of participant observation inside two firms and then conducted 84, in-depth, semi-structured interviews. Based on this data, Siciliano’s dissertation reports the following findings:

 

(1) Both routine and creative employees are required to self-manage and improvise their way toward the completion of daily tasks. In other words, the line between “creative” and “routine” appears blurred, with little distinction in terms of requisite skills. Insofar as creative and routine jobs in these industries require similar competencies and skills, they require the same sort of labor power – creative labor or task improvisation, often aided by information and communication technologies (ICTs), coupled with workers’ use of judgment. This creative labor requires generically human capacities for communication and unevenly distributed ICT competencies, yet managers and employers tended to undervalue these skills. Relatedly, this study finds that workers in both cases tend to be expected to be in round-the-clock communication with managers and clients. This blurs the line between work and leisure – a finding with potential policy implications described below.

 

(2) Control or power over creative labor within work processes tends to be linked to three forms of incentives. In the music case, managers use social networking opportunities and access to desirable technologies as ways to incentivize work. In the digital media case, management tends to incentivize work in the form of quotas and metric benchmarks. In both cases, Siciliano finds that workers report immersive, aesthetic experiences vis-à-vis workplace technologies. These self-reported moments of subjective immersion coincide with what workers define as the most satisfying parts of their job and so this represents another side of organizational power – one that gently encourages workers to expel more effort despite relatively low wages and unstable working conditions.

 

(3) Work in the digital media case tends to be more tightly linked to metrics due to the increased reliance upon digital infrastructures (i.e., platforms such as YouTube). While these infrastructures enable fast-paced production processes – often desirable and exciting for workers – the metrics that govern work processes often appear obscure and unclear to workers. Both routine and creative workers (office staff at a production company and on-screen talent throughout the U.S.) reported numerous instances in which metrics and other data provided by the platform frequently changed without notice or explanation. This suggests that while digital platforms provide increased labor market opportunities and increased labor market participation in media industries, the owners of platforms may exert an incredible amount of power over both workers and their employing organizations.

 

Broader Impacts

Beyond contributions to sociological theories of work processes and workers’ experience vis-à-vis technology, these findings may be of interest to labor policy in at least three ways. First, the around-the-clock communication requirements found in both cases blur the lines between work and non-work – a line that workers often struggle to maintain. This suggests a working day without end and thus suggests a need to examine regulation regarding workplace communication. Second, the undervaluing of requisite communication skills and technological competencies suggests a need to re-examine what we mean by the “digital divide.” As digital devices and communication systems (e.g., computers, smartphones, email, social media, texting, etc.) become more ubiquitous, the issue, from a labor perspective, is not longer access, but learned styles of communication. Third, findings from the digital media case suggest that platforms need seriously be considered as a significant labor issue. Structurally, YouTube production companies, their employees, and clients appear not wholly unlike other forms of platform-based employment. In the study, platforms did not technically employ any of the workers, yet the platform structured work processes – often in ways that seem arbitrary and obscure to both employers and their employees downstream.
